citations.narrative:
The four dolphins housed at Top Deck were discovered laying on the floor of their tank in seriously diminished water
levels, which resulted in various scrapes and abrasions on their chins, chests, pectoral fins, peduncles, and flukes. At
approximately 9:30 pm, on January 11, 2025, an employee began a routine backwash procedure of the pumps and filter
for Top Deck. The employee became distracted with another task and failed to follow written protocols. Instead of
stopping the process after 5 minutes, the backwash process continued to drain water from the tank for the next several
hours. Another employee also failed to follow written standard operating procedures by not routinely checking water levels
throughout the night. At approximately 5 am on January 12, 2025, the low water levels were identified, and the animals
were observed at the bottom of the tank with the injuries described above.
Failure to implement proper handling procedures exposes the animals to potential injuries and undue stress.
Handling of all animals shall be done as expeditiously and carefully as possible in a manner that does not cause trauma,
overheating, excessive cooling, behavioral stress, physical harm, or unnecessary discomfort. Corrective actions were put
in place and compliance was restored by the time of inspection.

At the time of inspection, the facility did not have documentation of participation for the employees required to participate
in their Life Support/Water Quality training.
Without documentation of a facility’s training courses, it is difficult to assess if an employee has the knowledge and skills
to adequately perform proper husbandry techniques, animal handling techniques, and reporting protocols. This can lead
to errors and have a negative impact on animal welfare.
The facility will provide and document participation in and successful completions of a facility training course for such
employees, that will include, but is not limited to, species appropriate husbandry techniques, animal handling techniques,
and information on proper reporting protocols, such as recordkeeping and notification of veterinary staff for medical
concerns.
To be correct by January 28, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
KRISTIN NAPOLI, SUPERVISORY ANIMAL CARE SPECIALIST n
